Detailed: The parents report that their infant has been slow to reach developmental milestones, including delayed motor skills like rolling over and sitting up. On exam, subtle dysmorphic facial features are noted, including upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, a flattened nasal bridge, and a protruding tongue. The patient presents with generalized hypotonia. A heart murmur is appreciated on auscultation. Though a definitive diagnosis cannot be made based on clinical findings alone, these features raise suspicion for an underlying genetic syndrome and warrant referral for genetic testing and evaluation by a pediatric specialist.

The patient presents with concerns of lower back pain and possible weakness or numbness in the legs. Upon examination, notable findings include a sacral dimple or hair tuft over the spine, possible asymmetry of the gluteal muscles, and decreased muscle strength or sensation in the lower extremities. The patient may have a history of inadequate folic acid intake around the time of conception. Further imaging such as an MRI would be warranted to evaluate for presence of a spinal cord malformation such as spina bifida.

The patient presents with concerns about facial asymmetry since birth, reporting difficulty feeding and nasal regurgitation of liquids. The parents note an unusual shape to the upper lip and concerns that speech development seems delayed. Examination reveals a unilateral cleft of the upper lip and hard palate, with nasal airflow visible when the child cries. There is poor coordination of suck and swallow noted during feeding evaluation.

The patient presents with fatigue, unexpected weight changes, feeling cold, constipation, emotional changes such as irritability or depression, muscle weakness, and dry skin and hair. Physical exam shows slowed reflexes, low blood pressure, a slow heart rate, puffiness around the eyes, enlarged thyroid, and loss of the outer part of the eyebrow. Lab tests show elevated TSH, low T3 and T4, elevated cholesterol, anemia, and vitamin deficiencies. These nonspecific findings warrant further investigation to reach a definitive diagnosis.

The patient presents with concerns about difficulty feeding and nasal regurgitation when bottle feeding their infant. Upon examination, a cleft is noted in the roof of the mouth. The parents report the child has difficulty creating suction and milk leaks out the nose when feeding. There is a visible defect between the lip and gum where the palate did not properly fuse during development in utero. The child cries excessively during feedings. Weight gain has been poor since birth.

The patient presents with flank pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Lab work shows reduced glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria. Imaging reveals a smaller kidney on one side with compensatory hypertrophy of the contralateral kidney. The patient may also have hypertension or chronic kidney disease.

Disease: Pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
Detailed: The patient presents with a productive cough of 3-4 days duration, complaining of pleuritic right-sided chest pain and shortness of breath with exertion. On exam, the patient is febrile at 38.5C, tachycardic at 105 bpm, and tachypneic at 22 rpm. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the right lung base. Chest X-ray shows an infiltrate in the right lower lobe concerning for pneumonia. Initial labs note leukocytosis of 15,000 cells/mm3 with neutrophil predominance.

A teenage male presents with behavioral concerns including attention difficulties, impulsivity, and minor learning disabilities. He is tall for his age and delayed in reaching some developmental milestones as a child. Physical exam is notable for slightly dysmorphic features including macrocephaly, hypertelorism, and clinodactyly. Genetic testing reveals an extra Y chromosome.

The patient presents with a mild backache and neck stiffness. Upon examination, reduced cervical spine range of motion and mild posterior midline protrusion in the neck are noted. The patient has normal strength and reflexes in the arms and legs. Initial findings are concerning for possible spinal or skeletal abnormalities, warranting imaging and neurological consultation to evaluate further.

The patient presents with a red, scaly rash on sun-exposed areas such as the face and arms that does not improve with over-the-counter moisturizers and worsens with sun exposure. On exam, the rash demonstrates erythema, scaling, and possible hyperpigmentation in a photodistribution pattern. There are no oral ulcers or joint complaints. Lab findings show positive ANA at 1:80 titer speckled pattern, but normal complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel. The subtle rash and positive ANA may point towards an underlying autoimmune process that warrants further evaluation and potential dermatology referral.

Disease: Congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens
Detailed: The patient is a male in his 20s or 30s presenting with a chief complaint of infertility despite unprotected intercourse with his female partner for over a year. He reports normal development through puberty and denies any significant medical issues or surgeries. On exam, the patient appears healthy with normal vital signs. Testicular exam is normal with no masses or tenderness. Semen analysis demonstrates azoospermia with normal ejaculate volume, pH, and fructose levels. Hormone testing shows normal FSH, LH, and testosterone levels.

The patient, a woman in her 50s, presents with persistent abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, and increasing urinary frequency and urgency over the past few months. She reports intermittent nausea but no vomiting. Physical exam is notable for a palpable mass in the abdomen upon deep palpation, though no obvious distension or ascites are noted. Lab work reveals an elevated CA-125 level. Imaging demonstrates complex adnexal masses concerning for malignancy. The patient has no significant past medical history.

The patient, a 45 year old female, presents with chief complaints of dry eyes, dry mouth, joint pain and fatigue that has been worsening over the past few months. On exam, notable findings include enlarged parotid glands and a positive Schirmer's test showing decreased lacrimal gland secretion. Lab work reveals a positive ANA as well as elevated ESR and CRP. The patient also endorses intermittent low-grade fevers and myalgias.

The patient, a man in his early 60s, presents with fatigue, weight loss, and frequent infections over the past few months. On exam, he has enlarged, non-tender lymph nodes in the neck, axilla, and groin. Labs reveal a high white blood cell count with many small, mature lymphocytes and reduced other cell lines. The lymphocytosis is monoclonal, with clonal B-cells present. The patient complains of drenching night sweats but denies fevers. He has no significant organomegaly or cytopenias. Overall, his presentation is concerning for a low-grade lymphoproliferative disorder. Further testing such as flow cytometry and bone marrow biopsy would be warranted to evaluate for leukemic cells.

The patient is a 6 month old infant brought in by his parents with concerns about his increasing head size and apparent developmental delays. On exam, his head circumference is noted to be 2 standard deviations above the mean for his age. Fontanelles are full and bulging. Ophthalmologic exam shows sunset eyes. The patient does not follow or reach for objects and has poor head control when pulled to sit. These findings would prompt neuroimaging and referral to neurosurgery to further evaluate suspected increased intracranial pressure.

The patient presents with abdominal distension and feeding intolerance evidenced by increased gastric residuals. On exam, the abdomen is distended but soft overall, with mild diffuse tenderness but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. The patient has mild metabolic acidosis on blood work. An abdominal x-ray shows mildly dilated loops of bowel with some air-fluid levels concerning for early bowel obstruction. Overall the findings and history would raise concern for an ischemic gastrointestinal process leading to compromise of the bowel wall integrity early in its course.

The patient is a pregnant woman in her third trimester who presents with new onset hypertension, proteinuria, and edema. She complains of headache, visual changes, and epigastric pain. On exam she has elevated blood pressure, 3+ protein on urinalysis, and peripheral edema. Labs are notable for elevated liver enzymes and low platelet count. These symptoms and findings could reflect underlying issues that require further evaluation and close monitoring of the patient and fetus.

The patient presents with concerns of amenorrhea and infertility after a recent dilation and curettage procedure. She reports gradual lightening and eventual cessation of her menstrual periods over the past few months. Upon exam, the cervical os appears stenotic and scarring or adhesions are noted within the uterine cavity. The patient may also report cyclic pelvic pain consistent with hematometra. These findings raise suspicion for intrauterine adhesions leading to obstruction. Further imaging and hysteroscopic evaluation are warranted to confirm diagnosis and determine management options.

The patient presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, abnormal renal imaging showing small and irregular kidneys, and slowly progressive chronic kidney disease. On exam, the patient has normal vital signs and no edema. Initial labwork shows an elevated serum creatinine and abnormal urinalysis with proteinuria and hematuria. The differential diagnosis is broad at this time, but the clinical presentation raises suspicion for an underlying congenital renal abnormality contributing to chronic kidney dysfunction. Further workup with additional imaging and potential genetic testing may be warranted to evaluate for causes of abnormal kidney development.

The patient presents with fatigue, night sweats, unexplained fever, and unintentional weight loss over the past few weeks. Physical exam is notable for enlarged, non-tender lymph nodes in the neck, armpits, and groin. Initial laboratory results show elevated lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid levels. These symptoms and signs may warrant further evaluation to determine the underlying cause. However, more information is needed to make any definitive diagnosis at this time.

The patient is a young girl who presents with delayed speech and language development. She has some learning challenges and struggles with reading, writing, and math in school. Her parents report that she started walking and talking later than most children. On exam, she has fairly subtle dysmorphic features such as epicanthal folds, a high-arched palate, and slightly low-set ears. Her height is above average for her age. Developmental testing shows delays in speech, language, motor skills and cognition.

The patient presents with several months of progressive skin thickening and tightening of the hands and face, along with fatigue and joint pain. On exam, there is notable thickening and stiffening of the skin on the fingers and face, with difficulty fully opening the mouth. Raynaud's phenomenon is present, with cold-induced blanching and cyanosis of the fingertips. Nailfold capillaroscopy shows capillary dilation and distortion. Anti-nuclear antibodies are positive at a titer of 1:320 in a speckled pattern. Together, these findings raise concern for an underlying connective tissue disease and warrant referral to rheumatology for further evaluation.

The patient presents with nonspecific symptoms including fatigue, shortness of breath, and abdominal discomfort. Physical exam reveals peripheral edema and a fluid wave/ thrill on palpation of the abdomen suggestive of ascites. Heart sounds are muffled and there are crackles audible at the lung bases bilaterally. Lab results are notable for anemia and low albumin. These findings warrant further evaluation to determine the underlying cause.

The patient, a 58 year old male with a history of smoking, presents with intermittent right flank pain over the past few months. He describes the pain as dull and aching, not affected by position changes. On exam, there is mild right costovertebral angle tenderness to palpation but no abdominal mass appreciated. Lab work reveals a normal complete blood count but slight elevation in creatinine at 1.3 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL). Urinalysis is positive for a small amount of blood but negative for infection. These findings warrant further diagnostic imaging to assess for any masses or abnormalities in the right kidney that may require follow up.

The patient presents with progressive numbness, tingling, and pain in the feet and hands that began insidiously a few years ago. Upon examination, decreased sensation to light touch and vibration is noted in a stocking-glove distribution. Reflexes are diminished at the ankles and there is mild distal weakness on manual muscle testing. The patient denies a history of diabetes or toxin exposure. Family history is notable for a parent diagnosed with a similar condition in mid-life.

The patient presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, and lightheadedness that has developed over the past few days. On exam, the patient is tachycardic, hypotensive, and diaphoretic, with jugular venous distension and crackles appreciated on lung auscultation. Initial workup reveals elevated BNP, troponin, and lactic acid concerning for decreased perfusion.

Disease: Acute sensorineural hearing loss by acute acoustic trauma or sudden deafness or surgery induced acoustic trauma
Detailed: The patient presents with acute onset of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss and tinnitus that began suddenly within the last few days. They deny recent upper respiratory infection, fever, vertigo, or other neurologic symptoms. On exam, the external ear canal and tympanic membrane appear normal. Hearing loss is sensorineural in nature. Tuning fork testing shows lateralization of Weber test to the affected ear and negative Rinne test on that side.

The patient presents with vague, nonspecific symptoms including fatigue, unintentional weight loss, lightheadedness, and easy bruising or bleeding. Initial lab work reveals anemia and elevated inflammatory markers. The physical exam is significant for enlarged tongue, periorbital purpura, and bilateral peripheral edema.

The patient presents with fatigue, nausea, abdominal discomfort, and loss of appetite. Lab results show elevated liver enzymes including ALT and AST. There is a history of hepatitis B infection in the past. Physical exam is significant for mild jaundice and tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. These symptoms and findings could reflect inflammation and damage to the liver consistent with early disease progression.

The patient presents with concerns of delayed development and growth in their infant. Upon examination, subtle microcephaly and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Lab testing reveals thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and evidence of intrauterine growth restriction. Careful review of the prenatal history is significant for suspected maternal infection during pregnancy. While a definitive diagnosis remains unclear at this time, the clinical picture raises suspicion for an underlying congenital infection as the source of the infant's presenting symptoms. Close monitoring of the infant's development and further directed diagnostic testing are warranted to elucidate the etiology.

The patient presents with occasional episodes of lightheadedness and palpitations over the past few months. During these episodes, the patient reports feeling their heart suddenly start to race before slowing back down. A thorough history reveals no clear triggers for these episodes. On exam, the patient is found to have an irregularly irregular pulse and a Holter monitor shows several short episodes of a fast heart rate around 160-180 bpm. Electrocardiography (EKG) is notable for a prolonged QT interval. Basic lab work including electrolytes is unremarkable. These findings are concerning for a possible underlying arrhythmia. Further evaluation and monitoring are warranted to determine the specific origin of the palpitations and guide appropriate treatment.

The patient presents with mild low back and flank pain that comes and goes, as well as occasional headaches. Lab tests show a gradual rise in serum creatinine over the past year and a decreasing glomerular filtration rate, though still within the normal range. Imaging reveals multiple bilateral renal cysts in different sizes, including some under 1cm in diameter. The patient has a family history of chronic kidney disease diagnosed at a relatively young age. Taken together, these findings warrant further evaluation and monitoring of kidney function to rule out possible causes.

The patient presents with complaints of shortness of breath and fatigue with exertion that has been slowly worsening over time. On exam, a systolic heart murmur is auscultated at the left upper sternal border. An echocardiogram shows evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy and post-stenotic dilatation of the pulmonary artery. There is also a peak Doppler gradient of 50mmHg across the pulmonary valve.

The patient presents with redness and pain in one or both eyes that has developed over the past few days. Upon examination, the eyes appear inflamed with some blurriness or reduced visual acuity. There may be photophobia or increased sensitivity to light. The patient may report headaches recently. Fundoscopic exam may reveal inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber and vitreous humor. Intraocular pressure could be elevated.

The patient presents with concerns about persistent fatigue, sensitivity to cold temperatures, constipation, and unexplained weight gain over the past few months despite no changes in diet or activity level. Physical exam is notable for dry skin, thinning hair, slowed reflexes, and a slightly enlarged thyroid gland. Initial laboratory results are significant for an elevated TSH level with a low free T4 level. These symptoms and exam findings, along with the abnormal thyroid labs, would prompt consideration of this diagnosis while additional testing is pending.

Disease: Moderate and severe traumatic brain injury
Detailed: The patient presents with headache, dizziness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating that started a few weeks ago after a motor vehicle accident. Physical exam is significant for photophobia, phonophobia, and irritability. Patient has difficulty with balance and coordination on exam. Memory and cognitive testing reveal issues with short-term memory, attention, and processing speed. Patient reports significant anxiety and depressed mood since the accident.

The patient presents with concerns about developmental delays, particularly delayed speech and language skills. On exam, subtle dysmorphic facial features are noted, including a long face, hooded eyelids, and a small mouth. The patient has a history of frequent sinus and ear infections since early childhood. Cardiac anomalies such as an atrial or ventricular septal defect may be discovered on workup. Immune dysfunction is evident based on the recurrent infections, and may warrant further immunologic testing if infections are severe or persistent.

The patient is a newborn or infant presenting with concerns about slow development and growth. On exam, findings may include enlarged anterior fontanelle, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and hypotonia. Labs would reveal elevated TSH and low T4.

The patient presents with fatigue, night sweats, and painless swelling in the neck, armpits or groin. Physical exam reveals enlarged, rubbery, non-tender lymph nodes in these areas. Initial lab work shows normal white blood cell count but low red blood cell count and low platelet count. The patient has no fevers, weight loss, or drenching night sweats.

The patient presents with acute onset of high fever, chills, headache, back pain, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On exam, the patient is febrile with a temperature of 103 F, heart rate of 110, and blood pressure of 100/60. Petechial rash is noted on the chest and abdomen. Lab results show thrombocytopenia, elevated hematocrit, decreased white blood cell count, elevated creatinine, and proteinuria. The patient reports recent travel to an area currently experiencing an outbreak of an unknown viral illness.

Disease: Non-papillary transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
Detailed: The patient presents with hematuria that has persisted for several weeks, describing intermittent painless bright red blood in the urine without clots. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria but no signs of infection. Past medical history is significant for smoking and occupational exposure to chemicals. Physical exam is unremarkable except for suprapubic tenderness.

Disease: High-grade dysplasia in patients with Barrett esophagus
Detailed: The patient presents with increasing heartburn and reflux symptoms over the past few months that are not well controlled with over-the-counter antacids or lifestyle modifications. They have a history of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease and have been taking a proton pump inhibitor daily for many years. Upon examination, the patient has tenderness in the upper abdomen. Initial laboratory results are significant for anemia and occult blood in the stool. The patient will need referral for an upper endoscopy to further evaluate the esophagus for any structural changes that may be causing these worsening symptoms.

The patient presents with fatigue, dizziness, shortness of breath, and occasional chest pain, particularly with physical activity. On exam, weakened femoral pulses and a blood pressure difference between the arms and legs may be noted. A cardiac murmur may be auscultated. Further workup reveals hypertension in the upper extremities compared to the lower extremities.

The patient presents with insidious onset of intense, generalized itching without skin lesions. The itching is severe, especially at night, and is significantly impacting quality of life. Initial lab work reveals an elevated creatinine level and decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate, indicating impaired kidney function. Physical exam is significant for dry skin. The patient has no rash or skin lesions.

The patient presents with rectal bleeding and changes in bowel habits such as increased frequency of stools, tenesmus, and urgency. The patient may also report rectal pain, pressure, or a feeling of fullness. On exam, findings may include contact bleeding, telangiectasia, friable mucosa or ulceration of the rectal mucosa visible on anoscopy or proctoscopy. The patient may have a history of pelvic radiation therapy.

The patient presents with moderate knee pain and swelling that has developed gradually over the past few months. The pain is localized to a specific area of the knee and worsens with physical activity, especially repetitive impact like running. On exam, there is tenderness when palpating the affected area of the knee and a slight decrease in range of motion.

The patient is a XX-year-old female presenting with complaints of frequent headaches and intermittent nausea and vomiting over the past several weeks. She reports that the headaches are typically worse in the morning. Upon exam, notable findings include prominent scalp veins visible across the top of the head, as well as abnormal neurological findings such as hyperreflexia of the lower extremities. Initial laboratory results are significant for mild anemia. Given the patient's symptoms and exam findings, additional targeted workup including neuroimaging studies would be indicated to further evaluate for any structural abnormalities that may be contributing to her clinical presentation.

The patient presents with a history of intermittent solid food dysphagia and episodic food impaction over the past few months. Symptoms seem to flare and then resolve spontaneously. There is no significant weight loss. Endoscopy shows rings and furrows in the esophageal mucosa as well as white plaques.

The patient presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath and episodes of cyanosis that are provoked by feeding or agitation. On exam, a heart murmur and Split S2 are appreciated. Chest X-ray shows boot-shaped heart silhouette. Echocardiogram reveals right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and pulmonary stenosis.

The patient presents with multiple light brown spots all over the body, known as cafe-au-lait macules, which appeared in early childhood. The parents report that the patient has always been clumsier than peers and has some learning disabilities that caused challenges in school. Upon exam, numerous benign soft bumps are noted over the skin.
